result.execSummary:
The defendant Michael S Yellowthunder was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Criminal Damage to Property [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.01(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

from defendant to Judge Brazeau
Absolute sobriety. No contact with D.Y. or residence. Child visitation arranged through Family Center. May obtain counseling with D.Y. in supervised setting.

4:05 Defendant Michael S Yellowthunder in court with attorney Eric Sheets.  Defendant Michael S Yellowthunder in custody.  Michael Daniel Zell appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Jacob Schar is sworn as a witness and questioned by Attorney Zell. He is a police officer with the Pittsville Police Department. On 12/1/15, he received a call regarding a disturbance at the residence in the City of Pittsville, Wood County. D.Y.'s father was the caller. He spoke to D.Y. She indicated that the defendant poured bleach on some clothes. He observed the clothes on the floor that appeared wet and changing colors and a bottle of bleach on the floor. D.Y. showed him a text from defendant indicating that he was going to bleach her clothes. He later spoke to defendant. The witness identifies the defendant in the courtroom. He stated that D.Y. bleached her own clothing. It appeared that the defendant had bleach stains on the clothes he was wearing. The following day, D.Y. recanted her story and said that she poured the bleach on the clothes. Attorney Sheets cross-examines witness. Attorney Zell redirects. Attorney Sheets cross-examines witness. 
Attorney Zell asks Court to take judicial notice of Wood County case 14CF418 that the defendant was on bond.
Attorney Zell makes statement.
Attorney Sheets makes statement.
Court finds probable cause that a felony was committed and the defendant committed it. Bound over for further proceedings.
Attorney Sheets requests that bond be modified to signature bond or lower cash bond. Victim makes statement regarding bond. She asks that no contact be removed from bond.
Attorney Zell opposes modification of bond. 
Court modifies bond to $2,000 signature bond with conditions of absolute sobriety. No contact with D.Y. or residence. Child visitation arranged through Family Center. May obtain counseling with D.Y. in supervised setting.
